title: 103_hr3372
content: The Act titled "Guam and the Northern Marianas Commemorative Coin Act" specifies the coin specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to issue 1,500,000 one dollar coins weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, and containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The design of the coins will honor the heroism of American forces in World War II, specifically those who liberated Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands. The coins will bear inscriptions including the years "1944-1994", "Mariana Islands", "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The coins issued under this Act will be considered numismatic items under section 5134 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary will obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Minerals Stock Piling Act. The design for each coin will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Delegate from Guam and the Resident Representative of the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, plus the cost of designing and issuing the coins, and a surcharge of $10 per coin. Bulk sales will be made at a reasonable account, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a discount. All sales will include the $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharges received from the sale of coins under this Act will be used to construct visitors centers and museums on Guam and Saipan, as specified by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary aims to issue coins by July 21, 1994, available for a year in uncirculated and proof qualities. Procurement regulations are waived for goods/services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. Financial assurance is required. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCE. The Secretary must ensure that minting and issuing coins will not cost the government. Payment for coins must be made in full, with satisfactory security or guarantee.
